    \let\PY@ul=\relax \let\PY@tc=\relax%

\def\PY@toks#1+{\ifx\relax#1\empty\else%

\def\PY#1#2{\PY@reset\PY@toks#1+\relax+\PY@do{#2}}

    \section{Inner Join, Outter Join, Left Join, Right Join, Row Bind,
Column Bind in
R}\label{inner-join-outter-join-left-join-right-join-row-bind-column-bind-in-r}

    The merge operations is well explained in the Pandas documentation which
can be found here . However, I could not find any documentation that is
as good as Pandas's for R. Hence, I have decided to blog about it.

    Let's say we have these two dataframes

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}38}]:} df1
         df2
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|ll}
 Country & Rank\\
\hline
	 US          & 1          \\
	 UK          & 2          \\
	 New Zealand & 3          \\
\end{tabular}


    
    \begin{tabular}{r|ll}
 Country & Population\\
\hline
	 US          & 300        \\
	 UK          &  80        \\
	 New Zealand &   4        \\
\end{tabular}


    
    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}2}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}import libraries}
        \PY{k+kn}{library}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{data.table\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
        df1\PY{o}{\PYZlt{}\PYZhy{}}\PY{k+kt}{data.frame}\PY{p}{(}Country\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kt}{c}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{US\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{UK\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+s}{\PYZdq{}}\PY{l+s}{New Zealand\PYZdq{}}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,}Rank \PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kt}{c}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+m}{3}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
        df2\PY{o}{\PYZlt{}\PYZhy{}}\PY{k+kt}{data.frame}\PY{p}{(}Country\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kt}{c}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{US\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{UK\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+s}{\PYZdq{}}\PY{l+s}{New Zealand\PYZdq{}}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,}Population \PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kt}{c}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m}{300}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+m}{80}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+m}{4}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    Before jumping to merging these two data frames, we can consider adding
one data frame to another. This procss is called binding in R, while it
is called concatenating in Python. There are two types of binding: row
binding (rbind function) and column binding (cbind function).

    \subsection{Row Binding}\label{row-binding}

    The \textbf{rbind} function appends the \emph{rows} of a data frame to
another data frame (hence the letter 'r' before 'bind'). However, for
this process to work, both data frames must have the same number of
columns and the columns in both data frame must have the same names;
otherwise, we will get the following error:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}23}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} df1 and df2 have different column names}
         
         df3 \PY{o}{\PYZlt{}\PYZhy{}} \PY{k+kp}{rbind}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

        Error in match.names(clabs, names(xi)): names do not match previous names
    Traceback:


        1. rbind(df1, df2)

        2. rbind(deparse.level, {\ldots})

        3. match.names(clabs, names(xi))

        4. stop("names do not match previous names")

    \end{Verbatim}

    However, if we try to bind df1 to another data frame which has the same
column names or itself, we get the following result

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}35}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}rbind of data frames with the same coulmn names}
         \PY{k+kp}{rbind}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df1\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|ll}
 Country & Rank\\
\hline
	 US          & 1          \\
	 UK          & 2          \\
	 New Zealand & 3          \\
	 US          & 1          \\
	 UK          & 2          \\
	 New Zealand & 3          \\
\end{tabular}


    
    Column Binding

    The \textbf{cbind} append a data frame with the columns of another data
frame ('c' stands for column). This operation does not require the same
column names. However, it requires that both data frames must have the
same number of row, otherwise, we will get this error:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}33}]:} \PY{k+kp}{cbind}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

        Error in data.frame({\ldots}, check.names = FALSE): arguments imply differing number of rows: 3, 2
    Traceback:


        1. cbind(df1, df2[1:2, ])

        2. cbind(deparse.level, {\ldots})

        3. data.frame({\ldots}, check.names = FALSE)

        4. stop(gettextf("arguments imply differing number of rows: \%s", 
     .     paste(unique(nrows), collapse = ", ")), domain = NA)

    \end{Verbatim}

    However, when the number of rows in both data frames is the same, here
is the result

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}34}]:} \PY{k+kp}{cbind}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|llll}
 Country & Rank & Country & Population\\
\hline
	 US          & 1           & US          & 300        \\
	 UK          & 2           & UK          &  80        \\
	 New Zealand & 3           & New Zealand &   4        \\
\end{tabular}


    
    \subsection{Summary of row and column binding in
R}\label{summary-of-row-and-column-binding-in-r}

    1- ** rbind ** appends the rows of a data frame to another. It requires
that both data frames have the same column names

2- \textbf{cbind} appends the columns of one data frame to another and
it requres that both data frames have the same number of rows

Let's say that you want to bind two data frames which have either
different column names or different row numbers, how can we do it? This
is when merging operation comes to play.

    \subsection{Outter Join (full)}\label{outter-join-full}

    let's say we want to append the following rows of df1 to df2, we can
only do it using outer join

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}55}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}only the fist and second rows of df2}
         df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}
         df1
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|ll}
 Country & Population\\
\hline
	 US  & 300\\
	 UK  &  80\\
\end{tabular}


    
    \begin{tabular}{r|ll}
 Country & Rank\\
\hline
	 US          & 1          \\
	 UK          & 2          \\
	 New Zealand & 3          \\
\end{tabular}


    
    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}51}]:} \PY{k+kp}{merge}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}all\PY{o}{=}\PY{n+nb+bp}{T}\PY{p}{,}by\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{NULL}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|llll}
 Country.x & Rank & Country.y & Population\\
\hline
	 US          & 1           & US          & 300        \\
	 UK          & 2           & US          & 300        \\
	 New Zealand & 3           & US          & 300        \\
	 US          & 1           & UK          &  80        \\
	 UK          & 2           & UK          &  80        \\
	 New Zealand & 3           & UK          &  80        \\
\end{tabular}


    
    However, you can see that there is redundant information. If we are to
use the 'country' column as a key or an idenitifer for both data frames,
then, we elimnate this redundancy and have this neat output.

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}62}]:} \PY{k+kp}{merge}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}all\PY{o}{=}\PY{n+nb+bp}{T}\PY{p}{,} by\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{Country\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} this is equilvant to merge(df1,df2[1:2,],all=T)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|lll}
 Country & Rank & Population\\
\hline
	 New Zealand & 3           &  NA        \\
	 UK          & 2           &  80        \\
	 US          & 1           & 300        \\
\end{tabular}


    
    The first value for the population of New Zealand is given 'NA' value
since we only used only the first and second rows of df2 and these two
rows don't have New Zealand.

    \emph{In short, the outer join when used with a key, it shows the union
of both data frames.}

    \subsection{Inner Join}\label{inner-join}

    The inner join is the oppoiste of outer join since its output is the
intersection of both data frames. The outer join operation replaces the
unaviloabe values with 'NA' while the inner join does not include it at
all.

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}61}]:} \PY{k+kp}{merge}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}all\PY{o}{=}\PY{n+nb+bp}{F}\PY{p}{,} by\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{Country\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} this equivlant to merge(df1,df2[1:2,]) since this is the default}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|lll}
 Country & Rank & Population\\
\hline
	 UK  & 2   &  80\\
	 US  & 1   & 300\\
\end{tabular}


    
    \subsection{Summary for outer and inner
join}\label{summary-for-outer-and-inner-join}

    1- The outer join outputs the union of two data frames

2- the inner join outputs the interesction of two data frames

3- The inner join is the default if no arugment other than the data
frames is provided

4- if no column name(s) are provided in the 'by' arugment, then the
column name(s) which are the same in both dataframes are to be used

    \subsection{Left and Right Join}\label{left-and-right-join}

    The left join is a type of outer join. However, it uses only the keys or
identifiers from the left table only (first table in the arugment).
Hence, it outputs the entire left table and replaces the missing values
from the right table with 'NA' or ommit them if they do not corospond to
any values in the key(s) column(s).

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}8}]:} \PY{k+kp}{merge}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}all.x\PY{o}{=}\PY{n+nb+bp}{T}\PY{p}{,} by\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{Country\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} replaces the missing values with NA for the right table}
        \PY{k+kp}{merge}\PY{p}{(}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}df1\PY{p}{,}all.x\PY{o}{=}\PY{n+nb+bp}{T}\PY{p}{,} by\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{Country\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} ommit New Zealand entries since New Zealand does not exist }
                                                    \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}in the country column of the left table}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|lll}
 Country & Rank & Population\\
\hline
	 New Zealand & 3           &  NA        \\
	 UK          & 2           &  80        \\
	 US          & 1           & 300        \\
\end{tabular}


    
    \begin{tabular}{r|lll}
 Country & Population & Rank\\
\hline
	 UK  &  80 & 2  \\
	 US  & 300 & 1  \\
\end{tabular}


    
    The right join is the same as the left join. The only difference is that
we are using the key(s) or idintifier(s) from the right table instead of
the left table. Here is the same code above but with the right join:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}12}]:} \PY{k+kp}{merge}\PY{p}{(}df1\PY{p}{,}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}all.y\PY{o}{=}\PY{n+nb+bp}{T}\PY{p}{,} by\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{Country\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} ommit New Zealand entries since New Zealand does not exist }
                                                     \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}in the country column of the right table }
         \PY{k+kp}{merge}\PY{p}{(}df2\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m}{1}\PY{o}{:}\PY{l+m}{2}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}df1\PY{p}{,}all.y\PY{o}{=}\PY{n+nb+bp}{T}\PY{p}{,} by\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s}{Country\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}  \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} replaces the missing values with NA for the left table}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{tabular}{r|lll}
 Country & Rank & Population\\
\hline
	 UK  & 2   &  80\\
	 US  & 1   & 300\\
\end{tabular}


    
    \begin{tabular}{r|lll}
 Country & Population & Rank\\
\hline
	 New Zealand &  NA         & 3          \\
	 UK          &  80         & 2          \\
	 US          & 300         & 1          \\
\end{tabular}
